62. Peterman, Elizabeth J. (Mrs. John T.)
WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Jane E.A. Perman
Address: Red Deer Hill, Sask.
Birthplace: Cornwall, England.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1914
Where did you set up housekeeping? Red Deer Hill, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Toronto, Ont.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? about once a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? sugar, tea, soda, salt, royal crown soda, coal oil.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? whatever
Was flour milled locally? Yes
In what quantities did you buy it? about 50 lbs per year
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ...........
How much did you use graham flour? not until 1916
Whole wheat flour? ..............................................
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 33
What year? ......
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...........
What other grain products did you use? grits
Cornmeal? ................. Whole wheat? ............... Farina? ...........
Other? beans & flour made good porridge
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? yes
How did you grind it? later with feed grinder coarse fine

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) **Well, drawn by lake**

How far was this water from your home? ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **by pail**

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We got a nice deep well close to house about 10 years after coming to homestead. Used lake water for washing. Lake was at foot of garden very handy for bathing in summer, skating in winter.
12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, stream, dugout). Well, drawn by lake.

If or far was this water from your home?

Here was it brought to the house? (Well, barrel, tank).

There was no water supply in my house which have taken place since you came here. I have been obliged to use what I could get from the well. We got a nice deep well close to house about 100 yards after we came here. We have had to haul water from the well for washing.

Note: There is a foot of garden away from the well.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Porridge with mild sugar, bread butter, tea potatoes, vegetable meat, potatoes cottage pudding, tea, bread, mixed potatoes green onions, omelet, wild fruit, tea hot biscuits, cold milk

Summer of 1894. 4 children ranging from 3 months to 8 years. In month of August.

18. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Roast pork plum pudding, can of tomatoes made into the best tomato soup ever was made, bread butter

Father mother & children. A neighbour & her girl of about 6 years.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Mother says no.
Porridge with milk sugar, bread butter, tea, bread, jam, potatoes, pudding, tea, bread, milk, onions, corned beef, wild fruit, hot biscuits, cold milk.

The summer of 1894, 4 children ranging from 3 months to 6 years, in March of August.

In the year 1894 you served your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada.

Grandfather's farm puddings, own of Amherstville.

With the help of friends, they were made.

When a neighbour's girl of about 6 years.

Spotted days, 1904.
